title: Manhattan: Central Park - 58th Street - 59th Street

text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, from West 58th (left) to 59th (right) Street's, showing the Plaza Hotel, opened to the public in 1890. It is set back from the Avenue with a small plaza and has Central Park on its north (right). Demolished in 1907, it was replaced with a new hotel structure of the same name.
1890's
Langill, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS UNKNOWN

First Hotel Plaza, Fifth Avenue, west side, from 59th to 58th Streets. This hotel was later razed (1907) and the present Hotel Plaza erected on its site.

August 15, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

August 15, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Fifth Ave., west side, between West 58th and West 59th Streets, showing prominently, the Pulitzer Memorial Fountain at the S.W. corner of West 59th Street. The fountain was erected from funds left by Joseph Pulitzer, and is constructed of limestone and consists of six basins rising in pyramidal form. In the center of the top basin, on a pedestal, is a bronze statue, eight feet high, of a nude female figure holding a basket of fruit. The fountain is often called the Fountain of Abundance. The sculptor is Carl Bittner, who lived from 1865 to 1915 and the architects are Carrère and Hastings. It was given to the city in 1916. August 15, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

South on Fifth Avenue from Sherry-Netherlands Tower at 58th Street, showing Heckscher Building in foreground.
About 1930.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Fifth Avenue, east side, at East 58th Street (center), showing north of that point the Savoy-Plaza Hotel (left) and south of same, the Squibb Building (right). This view is photographed in a south easterly direction from 59th Street and across a portion of the Grand Army Plaza, the latter occupying the west side of the Avenue, between 59th and 58th Streets. Partially shown on the extreme right is the Plaza Hotel.

About 1936

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.

Central Park: A view across the southeastern corner of the Park, showing prominently buildings on the east side of Fifth Avenue, between East 60th and 58th Streets. From left to right, these are, the Squibb Building, the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, the Sherry Netherland Hotel and the Ritz Tower. The latter is at the N.E. corner of Park Avenue and East 57th Street.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

Central Park: A view southeastward across the Boat Lake, showing buildings on the east side of Fifth Avenue, south from East 60th (left) to 58th (right) Streets. Prominent of these are, the Sherry Netherland, the Savoy-Plaza, and the Squibb Building.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad F.R.P.S.

Fifth Ave., at 58th Street, showing the Pulitzer Memorial Fountain, located on the west side of the Ave., between 59th and 58th Streets. This area is known as the Grand Army Plaza. It was erected in 1915 to the memory of Joseph Pulitzer, former owner of the New York World, and was sculptured by Karl Bitter. The fountain is surmounted by a bronze female figure symbolizing Abundance, bearing a basket laden with the fruits of the earth. It is often referred to as the Fountain of Abundance. At the extreme left appears a portion of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, at the N.E. corner of East 58th Street, and (center) a portion of the Squibbs Building, at the S.E. corner of the latter street. 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

Fifth Ave., west side, between West 58th (left) and 59th (right) Streets, showing the Pulitzer Memorial Fountain on the Plaza. It was erected in 1915 to the memory of Joseph Pulitzer, former proprietor of the New York World, and was sculptured by Karl Bitter. It is often referred to as the Fountain of Abundance. On the right appears a portion of the Hotel Plaza, which faces the Plaza.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

A Set of Seven Canvases of Old New York.

These paintings come from a country house called 'Glencairn' near Dublin in Ireland, where they adorned the walls of the billiard room. The house was built by Richard 'Boss' Croker (1841-1922), an Irishman who for many years was associated with Tammany Hall in New York, holding political positions under William M. 'Boss' Tweed, and later, after the latter's ousting, under 'Honest John' Kelly. Following the Lexow Committee investigations (1889-90), he left for England where he took up residence in Wantage, Berks., returning to America periodically, attempting to regain his lost position in the Democratic Party. After his final defeat in 1900, he crossed the Atlantic once again, built 'Glencairn' and started a racing stable. Despite his past reputation (he paid, in all, $550,000 for his Irish estates), he lived up to the high standards demanded by British racing circles, and when his horse Orby won the Derby in 1907, did not even back him.

These pictures were painted to remind him of New York, and it is assumed that they were executed here around the turn of the century. All are painted in tones of sepia and green.

The British Government has recently acquired this mansion for the use of the British Ambassador to Ireland.
